item.title: Namespaced Role and RoleBinding
item.description: Role and RoleBinding is used to create roles and bindings in particular namespaces.

item.title: Access kubernetes APIs using token
item.description: Access kubernetes API using service accounts and tokens.

item.title: Node Authorization
item.description: Node authorization implemented specially for kubelet for access kubernetes resources.

item.title: Attribute Based Access Control (ABAC)
item.description: ABAC involves access control policies in policy file which contains users and their respective access controls.

item.title: kube-apiserver
item.description: kube-apiserver enables accessing kubernetes cluster using API requests.

item.title: Authorization in kube-apiserver
item.description: Authorization in kube-apiserver has mainly four implementations viz, Node, ABAC, RBAC and Webhook.

item.title: API Groups
item.description: API groups is a collection of APIs kube-apiserver provides. For example api for health, metrics, logs, resources etc. There are mainly two groups core apis and named apis. Core apis have resources like pods, namespaces, configmaps, etc. Named api group has resources like apps, networking, authentication, certificates etc. Named api group will be used mostly for future resources.

item.title: kubectl Proxy
item.description: kubectl proxy command sets up the proxy server which uses kubeconfig and enables users to access kube-apiserver.

item.title: KubeConfig
item.description: kubeconfig configuration file holds the information required for kubectl command to work. It holds information about various kubernetes clusters, users and contexts. Contexts are the links between what users are tied to what clusters. It also has a current-context field which specify which context is being used by kubectl in present.
